Most women will get sexually harrassed or abused at some point in their lives. It usually happens when they're young and pretty. And the creep is almost always an older male. It makes a lot of women feel very cautious and mistrusting of older men who may or may not be into them.

How 'old' you seem has an impact, btw.
If you're 27 and your gf is 20, that's not a huge age gap. But if you have your own place, car, a good job, and are almost finished your studies, you're gonna look like a massive creep dating a girl who still lives with her parents and still has a young/irresponsible mindset and very little real life experience.

If you're 27 and you act 'younger', you're not gonna seem nearly as creepy dating a 20yo. Especially if she generally has her shit together. The only exception to this rule is if you're kind of a fucking loser.

It sounds like your ex felt like you guys were a good match, mentally. Maybe she viewed you as a 'young' type of guy, despite your age. And maybe she felt that she had her shit together enough to be your equal in most matters, despite her own age. Idk. She probably doesn't feel like she was groomed, and looking back on when you met, realised that you were a decent guy when you met, so it was ok.

Is it hypocritical? Kind of, yeah.
But in fairness, people with this mindset aren't actually bothered by the AGE of either party. They're more creeped out by grooming (which anyone can do to anyone, regardless of their respective ages), and they're creeped out by the inappropriateness of the pairing as people.

>>28230007

I've been the woman in this situation.
She's not using you for compliments. If she wanted compliments, she would egg you on to say more, to stroke her ego.
She IGNORED your compliment because she didn't like the flirty tone, but couldn't be certain whether you intended for it to sound flirty. She had three options here:
>Assume it was just friendly and accept the compliment. With the risk that you ARE in fact flirting, and that this course of action will egg you on to flirt more - creating an awkward situation.
>Assume it was flirty, and inform you that she's not interested. With the risk that you weren't flirting at all, and potentially embarrass herself and insult you by misjudging your intentions.
>Ignore the compliment entirely, to hint that she is not interested in your possible flirting, while maintaining friendly communication with you in general, to let you know that she's still friendly towards you.

I think this interaction is a strong indicator that she likes you as a person and likes talking to you, but is trying to avoid any possible flirty interactions because she doesn't see you in that way.
Which fucking sucks for you. Sorry, mate. It be like that sometimes.
But on the plus side, she clearly doesn't think you're some kind of creep or annoyance, or she wouldn't still be talking to you.

Don't stress about it. You've done nothing wrong or weird and she gets that. If this kind of thing happens once in a while, it's not a big deal.

This would only become a problem if it kept happening. If you keep making semi-flirty comments and she keeps hinting at you to stop, and you ignore it, she's gonna block you. If you are careful to act platonically towards her, you can keep the friend.
Of course, whether you're interested in being friends instead of trying to get with her is a different matter. That's up to you, bro.

posts.sub: I don't want to be a porn addict any longer.
posts.com:
This is my first 4chan post, so I apologize if that's too apparent. I came here because I figured you all might understand + it's anonymous.

I have a porn addiction. My sexual desires outweight my moral compass and my desire to be a better person.

I am neurodivergent and my brain latches strongly onto pieces of media that I like. My problem is: Everytime I really like a piece of media, I have the overwhelming urge to find porn of it. I believe that I don't even want to see the porn; it disgusts me at the same time that it entices. I have struggled with this bad habit for years.

A few weeks ago I saw Puss in Boots: The Last Wish in cinema, and I absolutely loved it. Again, there was that nagging desire to find porn of my favorite characters. I held out for a few days before caving, again: I always do.

Fast forward to today. I saw a regular, innocent piece of fanart of Puss, and it turned me on. Pavlov tried to warn me, but I didn't listen.

I'm tired of ruining the things I love with lust, guilt, and shame. I am tired of struggling this way. Has anyone here recovered from porn addiction? Any advice?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28227667
Learn how habits develop and how dopamine works. The youtube channel "What I've Learned" has some excellent videos on this, both in general and specifically relating to porn. It will help you understand why you've become like this and how to fix it.

Now, first task is to stop fucking masturbating to r34. You are massively reinforcing the pathway of:
>see or think of fictional character you like
>search for r34
>coom (literally one of the biggest rewards you can give your brain)
and that trench in your brain will get deeper and deeper until you stop.

Next would be to stop the browsing habit. if you're not cooming but still looking at r34 shit you're still running down the same pathway, just not reinforcing it enough. If you want to look at fanart you make goddamn sure it's wholesome and absolutely sfw. If you feel lust, make a list of what you'll do instead of firing up private browsing and going to a booru. Something like "I'll go grab a glass of water" or "I will do 5 pushups" or "I will read a chapter of a (NON-LEWD) book". Try finding a new hobby that won't trigger your coomer habit.

The fact you feel shame, disgust, and guilt is good. Your conscience is intact. You don't want to be this way deep down. You've just got tracks in your brain compelling you to behave this way, like wagon ruts in a muddy road, but if you use the willpower and techniques to keep dragging yourself through those ruts, they will fill in eventually and you will be able to enjoy things without perverting them.

t. recovering hentai addict

You absolutely do want to see it.

You will never willpower your way to freedom.

Instead imagine a version of yourself that has quit. Ask yourself: what has he understood that I haven’t?

Two prongs to making it clear to someone that they're in the friendzone: Talk to them about other girls, and compliment them on what a good friend they are.
You need both. Talking about other girls clearly signals your disinterest in her, but the compliment makes her feel good and see that she does have value to you the way things are, that you aren't just completely oblivious/indifferent to her feelings.
If you only compliment her on her friendship, she might see it as an opening. If you only signal interest elsewhere, she might feel compelled to charge with abandon through that seemingly closing window of opportunity, not realising it's one of those cartoon windows painted into a cliff face and she was never gonna make it in the first place.

I think taking a break in this situation is a bit different, because she doesn't exactly have time to look for 'someone better.' And if you're not inclined to look elsewhere either, there's a high chance you'll come back together at the end of it.
Most of the time couples take a break, it's because the relationship itself isn't working and they need a break from being around each other. It's also not that the break causes the breakup, but that wanting a break in the first place is a symptom of the need to break up, and for some, provides the necessary emotional ease-in to being able to break up.
What you guys are dealing with is temporary external factors that are preventing the relationship from even being active.

I don't wanna tell you that you guys are the exception and it's gonna work out, I just think you have to think on how you actually feel here and let that guide you, rather than worrying about any illusion of correlation between breaks and breakups. Would you feel secure if you guys went on a break? Would it ease the problems you're going through, or make them worse? Would it make you feel better or would you just be sacrificing your own peace of mind for hers?

>>28234047
>Sometimes I wonder how men and women manage to communicate at all.
kek, totally.

>A: cowardly
Welcome to women, lol

>and B: really calculatedly cruel.
Whether it's cruel depends on the delivery. Like, imagine a scenario where there's absolutely no romantic interest between these people. In that world, there's nothing cruel about a guy saying "man, how about these apps." It's a normal thing for friends to talk about. So just like trying to give someone a plausibly deniable hint that you're interested in them, it works as a plausibly deniable hint that you're not.
Bad hints of disinterest can be cruel, but no more than bad hints of interest can be harassment. It's all in the execution.

I can only speak for myself, but if I'm interested in someone, I'm going to be keeping my eye out for clues of whether they're A) interested in me, B) oblivious to my existence, or C) outright disinterested.
If I'm not ready to be direct with a guy about how I feel, I can't very well expect him to both read my mind, and be the one to take the initiative to sit me down and be direct with me about how HE feels. So him (intentionally or not) sending clear signals that he's outright uninterested gives me something I can use to decide "ah, see, I'm barking up the wrong tree." And sure, it hurts, but rejection's always gonna.
But the only workable alternative is for him to just play dumb, and with that I'll either be stuck in a purgatory of thinking "well he might be uninterested, but maybe he's just oblivious?" or I'll put all my cards on him being oblivious and either double down on trying to get him to take a hint (and there seems to be no end to the obviousness of hints that a guy can theoretically miss, so that could end in a real arms race) or I put myself out there and have to face direct rejection, then somehow try to go forward pretending nothing ever happened.
So yeah, figuring out how he feels from the shadows is very much the more socially safe option to me.

>>28234108
>she keeps leaving it up to me to break up/take a break/third option
It seems like she just feels like she's being cruel by keeping you 'tied down' without actually giving you anything for your trouble, and is concerned that you'll lose interest or become resentful if the situation continues.
But if you're happy enough to deal with her not being able to really give you any sort of attention while she tackles all this, I'd say stick it out. Just be clear about your expectations of one another, so she knows where the bar is, because it's probably a lot lower than she thinks. So if you're like "all I want is to be able to call you my gf and send you cute encouraging messages and maybe get a heart-react now and then," that'll allow her to relax about the fact that she's not hanging out with you every night and meeting you for lunch and sleeping with you x times a week, etc etc etc.
Think about the bare minimum you're willing to accept from her during this time to still feel like the relationship is alive and you're respected as a partner, and talk through that with her to figure out what's realistically possible on her end. If there's no middle ground that can be reached (basically, if you need more than she's able to give you - and it's not wrong for you to need that), then yeah, a break or breakup might be for the best. But if you're satisfied with the extent of what she can give you, then yeah, just reassure the hell out of her that she's meeting expectations and that you're happy so she can put the worry out of her mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28232031
>social issues
Because I was diagnosed so late, I had already gone through years of social awkwardness and finding techniques to hide/mask my inner dialogues and urges to speak out. Diagnosis just made me okay with the fact I don't typically fit in. Obviously you and I can have very different issues, so traction may very. I have a few ticks based on stimulus I have to hide, otherwise it's pretty hard to tell I'm on the spectrum.

>techniques - sort of like masking
I have always been a very calculated, rule oriented, structured person, and my social life has essentially come down to running what I call 'programs' on the fly. If I'm in a room of older women, I have a persona for that, a room of burly construction guys, if I'm at a funeral etc. I am basically adjusting who I am to meet the scenario I'm in. It's a muscle that you need to exercise regularly, and requires space to offgas the tension of covering over your actual feelings later. The catch to all this is having a hard time building authentic relationships, it took a lot of effort to find other people like me to be myself around, including my now wife.

>work
Find any shitty job that puts you in front of people and just practice social interaction and learning what normal people do in different situations. Force yourself to make eye contact and build your own repository of data for how to exist in the world. I often wonder if this is appropriate advice, as it denies who you are, but the gubberment wont pay me enough to just be myself, making me have to work and thus know how to blend in and exist.

Similar situation here, OP.

>33
>Long term GF
>Several GFs before current one
>Healthy friendships
>Good job

I learned to mask much earlier than I learned what masking was. In Elementary school I noticed I was awkward and didn't understand the behaviors of my peers. Rather than blame them like many autists would, I blamed myself.

I carefully observed what was appropriate and what wasn't, what the proper emotional response for each situation was to emulate my peers.

By middle school, I had most my behaviors down, although HS was a bit rough at the start.

Accept that you're broken, not society. Learn the behaviors that are instinctual for non autists. It requires willingness to make mistakes and for you to develop better self awareness. The worst part of autism is the innate selfishness you feel, you need to overcome that.

Eventually you can mask as a functional human being and find a partner.

>>28226460
I think there is an underlying assumption in your thinking. You’re basically saying

>why would anyone do anything if it can’t give me what I was looking for

The thing is you’re right. You can’t find what you were looking for in achievements and worldly rewards. It’s like when you fall in love, and you put the other person on a pedestal. You’re simply asking too much. You’re running from what life really is. And by doing so, you’re missing it. And that’s why you feel like you are not whole, and that you need something, that you know the world cannot bring.

One of the big problems of human thought is that we are too quick to believe what we hear. In place of genuine understanding, we believe. And we often call those beliefs knowledge, and invest ourselves in them. And we base the most important decisions in our lives on those beliefs.

You said you can’t force it. That’s right. That’s what acting out a belief feels like. It’s an idea, that has its own emotional energy, that you allow to run you. It feels forced and artificial, because something deep inside of you knows it isn’t you. And what I’m telling you right now could easily turn into that as well. Little packets of self-image, emotion, thought and behaviour, that you try out as if they’re a costume. There’s nothing wrong with that at all. Genuinely. But it’s important to know what it is, and what it isn’t. And here is what it’s not: it isn’t the truth. And it isn’t you. Yet we cling to all sorts of beliefs as if they are both. All of self-help is essentially nothing more than than looking for an idea that you can cling to, and act out. And it never works. Because it’s just conditioning.

The only way doing and achieving in the world will be a joyful experience for you, is if you fully see that yes, it can give you all kinds of experiences. But it can never give you the ultimate. And therefore it can never be allowed to feel quite that serious.

And nothing is sacred, no lie is too great, when it comes to concocting a scheme to feel good all the time. You can really hurt yourself with it. We really want those bulletproof, consistent narratives about ourselves, but a person is much more slippery than that. All the stories about why we do things are never true. Ask yourself what a person from the outside would see. He would call your bullshit real fast. Your struggle is a role you’re playing. I know this sounds ludicrous, which is why it’s important that you don’t believe it. And the only way anything changes is by looking with fresh eyes, so you can start to see how that role is playing out. You’re an actor lost in his role. And any attempt to change, fix, manipulate, is just undertaking a new role. This is how a self-image is created. The reason it’s a self-IMAGE is because it isn’t real. It is something that is held in place of first-hand knowledge of who you really are. And the conditioning compells to make your self-image conform to what the world has imprinted on you. The reason that never leads to a transformation is because you are manipulating something that’s just an image to begin with. How could it ever be of any real consequence to you?

>>28227251
The truth doesn’t give you problems. The truth untangles and relieves, without any attempt to be untangled and relieved. If a problem remains, you have not understood it.

For a long time I was stuck between a cycle of self-improvement, which is one behavioral-thought-emotion ecosystem I could cycle around in, without ever getting anywhere… And then giving up, which was basically a rebellion. Going to the place that I instinctively perceived to be the opposite of the self-improvement thing. But still just a system of behaviour, thought, emotion… Attitudes and beliefs I had been exposed to that appealed to me.

Both of those suffer from the fact that I am trying to get somewhere by adopting an attitude, and trying to feel a certain way. It’s trying to play a role. But it’s all I knew. To me that was very real. But no matter how much you believe you are going somewhere, you always end up back at square one. You can not run from who you are.

Any true transformation doesn’t occur by adopting an attitude and landscaping yourself. There’s nothing to “fix”.

Here’s an example of a behavior you are not caught in: You are not compulsively learning every Drake song by heart so that you may be considered a true Drake fan. Why? Because you just genuinely don’t want to. You didn’t have to wrestle yourself or fix yourself to avoid it.

If you find yourself on the path to mastering the piano, it should come equally as easily. It isn’t an activity that you have orchestrated. It comes from just looking at life, looking at the attitudes you’ve adopted, not with the intention that you will try to drop any of it. Not with the intention that there’s anything to fix. Seeing that every single thing you’ve ever “decided to do” was done by forcing upon yourself an attitude. When you were a kid and you played with a toy, that just happened. And when your understanding of life organically grows, you will likewise begin changing without

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28227568
trying to. And the change will be for the better. It’s much like discovering you’ve been compulsively learning every Drake song to be considered a Drake fan, and you just go “well, let’s not do that anymore lol”… There’s no struggle to it.

And as I speak those words, and you try to understand, you’ll form an idea about how it happens, and then you’ll adopt that as an attitude. Trying to get there by mimicry, disguised as something deeper. And you will be back to square 1.

Every piece of advice you’ve ever read has been packaged and adopted as an attitude.

None of the stuff you’ve ever done organically had any reason behind it in the fashion you are trying to arrive at now. You just did it. The mess of confusion you are in doesn’t need to be resolved. It needs to be seen without the slightest hint of trying to have a realization that finally fixes you. Which means you stop trying. Without adopting an attitude of depression. This life is for you, it’s about what you want. After you’ve seen that the NEED to want something is nothing but a frantic, fleeing pleasure chase. Everyone wants something at a more genuine level. It could be as simple as living in a cottage, making your own food, and having a dog and a family.

>this thought scares me
It is your conditioning that is scared. For me, I had to ask myself whether the anxiety of missing my potential actually helped. You see, it never goes away. There’s no standard to reach, after which it stops. And it poisons everything. It never helped me, and I wish I had never bought into it to begin with. Because when there are things you cannot accept, you cannot grow. I can tell you it’s a very beautiful experience to finally trust yourself. You’ll discover that the creature you’ve been running away from is actually who you really are, and where your soul and genius is. You think you need to be in charge to keep your bad habits in check, but the only reason you have bad habits is because you need to cope with being tyranized by the voice of an internalized society. Conditioning. A blind idiot. Always telling you you need to conform to some image to be good, but always moving the goal post. That anxiety, I will call it, couldn’t orchestrate greatness if its life depended on it. It always leaves its ugly validation seeking stench on everything. The only way you can get to your potential, and the only way it’s worth it, is if you go without that voice.

I’ll tell you a story. It’s about a famous pianist in his early 20s. He was in a mess, broke, unhappy love, and he decided to end it. But the attempt failed. But something very interesting happened. When he went into the street again, life was completely new. He said life’s just what it gives you, right in front of you. And he became one of the greatest pianists of the 20th century. Can you understand what happened to him? What do you think left him? He let go of something. And after that, he thought life was over, but when the suicide attempt failed, he discovered everything that remained.

Notice will come to him at your address - or to him by email - saying the contract is ending and giving him the price of renewal. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Therapy for the dread.

You probably need a goal or meaning in life. I want to become an artist, so there is my motivation for a clean room. If you have no goal, why clean your room if you don't mind the dirt? (obviously no overly rotten food or equal)
I think a lot people wouldn't do anything if not for the necessity of doing a job for money. So while you are privileged, it may be hard and unnatural to do anything.

What would you wanna do? Just work towards that. Write down the literal next step (that you can physically do). Try and fail, repeat it until you get it done, it may take years.

If you don't know what or don't feel like anything interests you, just choose "randomly" and start with that, you will learn if you like it after putting in some 100 hours.

posts.sub: In this thread we are going to look for the cure for depression
posts.com:
I have no proof or medical studies to show that this is the case, but I also have no doubts. I believe that to get out of depression, tiredness, fatigue and all that shit, you first have to work your body, since a healthy body is a healthy mind, for that it is good to do sports, whatever it is. it is as long as it keeps our body busy. Another important factor is studying, it doesn't really matter what, it doesn't matter if it's for university, school or for yourself, you have to do it to keep your mind occupied with something productive. I would also say that looking for a job, or generating income with a startup, as this will keep our mind and body busy, while giving us money, in itself gives us a reason to keep going, especially when you are working on something of your own.

Another important point is to stop comparing yourself to others, stop thinking that the other is better than you because you have more knowledge, money or physical condition. It is also very silly to think about issues such as superiority or inferiority, we are all human, we all have problems and difficulties in life, of course there are degrees of this, but this does not have to be a limitation. You have to focus on yourself, on your problems, on your virtues, on your life, and not on that of others.

Another issue is guilt and remorse, which depending on the person can be the easiest part, or difficult to overcome, because it is easy to forgive others, but sometimes it is difficult, if not impossible, to forgive yourself. No matter how dirty your hands are, they can always be cleaned. You have to accept your sins, accept what you did wrong and live with it. Go to a priest, a psychologist, or tell someone you trust what you did, this can help, it doesn't matter if you think psychology is a joke, or if you don't believe in God, the important thing is to somehow get the weight off What are you wearing.

posts.com: think you need to begin with the question of why do people in general feel emotions to begin to answer why someone would fall into a perpetual negative emotional state. Emotions are clearly intrinsic instincts not learned although learned experiences can change what triggers the emotions to occur. These instincts evolved over time to prod people towards the actions that have proven to be evolutionarily successful over time. Because people are highly social animals and there is fierce competition between different social groups of people, many of the emotions we feel are actually designed to not simply benefit yourself and improve your own survival, but to benefit the survival of the entire social group. These instincts go hand in hand with developed cultural mores.

It all comes down to conditioning.

From the most recent trigger or episode to your emotional trauma that sets off depression.
Or the cycle of trauma and pain you repeat and keep yourself in.
Down to traumatic events that have a lifelong impact on your psyche.

The necessary systems in place for recovery are 'safety', 'hope of recovery and future', an environment that fosters these two things as well as the social justice aspect, meaning you get the recognition of trauma you were dealt and the perpetrator dealt with. (but in the case of Act of God events, it's rationalisation through the reality of what happened)

This means, identifying things in your environment and social groups as well as your past, that negatively affect you. Doing your best to distance and remove those obstacles in your life and then having the 'stability' of an environment that is conducive to positive feedback cycles and a normalisation of ptsd behaviour responses in order to become and feel normal.

Lack of hope is another big reason, but this falls back to conditioning and a lack of positive feedback cycles fueling your worldview. If your metaphysical understanding of the universe is lacking, you won't see the point of your individualism in the big picture.

>or develop another useful schema (evolution)


Depression is just when life beats you down and you lack the insight and motivation or opportunity to actually make a change. It's as simple as that.

My depression started when I was 13 years old, I didn't bathe, I had constant nightmares, I didn't eat, I was sad and with a feeling of emptiness all the time. I was very afraid of dying and leaving this world. But I don't know what happened that I saw how a car hit my brother and all those feelings left.
A couple of years later when I had made a good business, I went back into that fear of death, but do you know why that didn't last long? Because I had a project, I was going to do my first crop, I worked, I thought about how we could do things better, I learned, that really got me out of that state of anguish, fear, and emptiness. Then, of course, I went to do a sport, and took some medicine, and the truth was that they did me good.

As someone who has been through the psych treatment ringer, I think this is solid advice for most people.

In my opinion, it's impossible to go wrong with the advice initially posted here. In my opinion, the road to finding effective psychiatric treatment is often counter productive anyway. Being kind to yourself is free.

As a non-depressed Anon, from the outside looking in, it is interesting to me that many depressed people have the following attributes:

1. Distrust or highly competitive against "outsiders".
2. Focused on helping themselves instead of helping others.

I believe these are directly related to the depression itself. You see yourself as in an endless competition with the rest of society, and since you cannot help others (because to do so would be to harm yourself in this "competition" you have envisioned), it is also impossible to ask others for help. By folllowing this mindset, you cut yourself off from the very socialization and trusting relationships that would actually help you to recover. Since you do not help others, you yourself cannot be helped.

We cannot say whether or not you should take antidepressants, you must attend one or two sessions with a psychiatrist and tell him about your problems, and he will determine whether or not you have depression. You can be a functional, charismatic person, who bathes, goes to work, studies, and does everything well, but if apathy (loss of interest in things), a feeling of emptiness, and physical symptoms such as fatigue from nothing , then you may have depression, especially with those suicidal thoughts that you have.
Therapy can also help, but if you go to several sessions, tell them all your problems and see that it doesn't help you, it's better to change someone better. Do not stay with the first option, if you do not like something you are always free to go and change.

>>28216868
Here’s you. You don’t know yourself very well.

And over there is society, your parents, peers etc. Tv screens, schools… They’ve been telling you all your life what a “good person” is. Maybe you felt you are not good enough the way you are.

That causes trauma. Sounds dramatic, but all it means is that pain causes you to reject certain aspects of yourself.

This rejection functions by repression, preventing who you are from being made conscious. And therefore you have low self-awareness. You also have a feeling of need. You don’t feel whole.

For the places where you rejected yourself, you do not know what you really want. You’ve disconnected from yourself. Instead, what you’re doing is aspiring to make yourself conform to the image society has programmed onto you. This is the trap of self-image.

The maintenance of a self-image is a burden, motivated by anxiety and pain. You may be good at it, or you may be so handicapped by it, that it extinguishes you, and it completely prevents you from knowing what you actually want.

In the latter example, you are sure you know what you want, you just “can’t get yourself to do it”. It is the poor self-awareness at work, because of the trauma. And that is how you get depressed.

It is getting stuck in a lie, that you are unwilling to let go of (that you have to be/do better), because you are sure that you are worthless as you are.

>Complete abstinence from drugs

>family first (idk what else to call it)
She considers me socially detached because I'm not in a relationship, and she said being in a relationship would be the number one sign of social rehabilitation. I don't want a relationship. I've never wanted a relationship. Please leave me alone.
>forced to take the meds
My medication genuinely helps me, but if I were to suddenly stop taking it she could have me committed because that's also 'self-harm' in our legislation.
>rejection of unconventional ideas
Do NOT bring up unconventional ideas or – even worse – philosophy up with a psychiatrist. I did that once in a psychiatric hospital. The discussion was honestly dumb, and it's difficult to explain. Either way, he constantly misrepresented everything I said, for hours on end, and when that really started to piss me off, he said that I was manic and had me put on a higher dose of medication. You can't refuse meds in a psychiatric ward; if you do, they will literally force it down your throat with a funnel. I've seen it happen.

1/2

No.

I should stop worrying about this. In 2017/18 I was so worried about lumps in my neck but they're still there after 6 years and it turned out to be nothing. In 2019 I was convinced I had lung cancer because of a nagging cough and phlegm but that went away too for reasons unknown. 2020 I thought I had heart disease, 2021 I thought I had type 1 diabetes, 2022 I thought I had a brain tumour. None of this stuff turned out to be real, but I have spent dozens of sleepless nights worrying, days off in doctors offices and thousands of dollars on medical bills over this bullshit. These red dots are most likely just another one of those things, and they don't seem as threatening as some of the other symptoms I had which turned out to be nothing. The cost of worrying about every little thing outweighs the benefit of the low chance of catching on to something early. I should just live day to day and stop caring so much. If it's serious, it'll let me know that eventually, but until then I gain nothing from worrying and I lose a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Psychologists don't have patients, they have clients.

If they gave you a copy of the report or sent it to your doctor they haven't hidden anything to you and have met their duty of care. They didn't want to see you any further. It's the responsibility of you and your physician to read through the report together and have the physician explain everything to you.

That you're just reading through it with a doctor now and still don't know what the next steps are tells me that your physician is terrible at his/her job and you should find a new one.

Autism is a spectrum these days, and it ranges from exceptionally mild which would classically be no diagnosis at all to physically non-functional. It's ultimately a neurodevelopmental disorder where the person does not develop mentally beyond a particular age from childhood. If that age is somewhere in their mid-late teens no problem. If that age is a few months old, big problem. Where you sit on that spectrum determines what, if any, supports you require.

Simply having an autism diagnosis is not enough to be eligible for supports. Autism is not treated with therapy, it's managed where necessary by case workers whom are little more than over qualified childcare assistants.

Similarly, anxiety comes in different degrees and types. Social anxiety is very different than general anxiety for example. Mild general anxiety is very different to severe general anxiety. What type of anxiety you have, and to what degree, will likewise determine whether you need any treatment at all, and if so, what.

So, for example if you had mild general anxiety and were a 1 on the autism spectrum, you wouldn't need any further treatment. Historically in that situation you wouldn't receive any diagnosis at all. It's only that post modern psychology is obsessed with labelling everything that there is a diagnosis in that scenario. In other words if you had mild general anxiety and a 1 on the autism spectrum, there's nothing wrong with you.

Growing up, I was really aloof. I didn’t desire much, so even though I had little I wasn’t suffering. (Perhaps I had some minor depression but my mind didn’t register it.) Later in life, when I first “self-improved” I was happy because my bar was set low. I started from nothing and made modest gains and got everything I thought I wanted. When I lost it all, I didn’t really comprehend I might not got back what I had . Afterwords, I just sort of “went with the flow” of life, and was generally content , albeit with moments of discontent.

Nowadays, it seems desire rules my life. I feel immense frustration over all the missed opportunities and mistakes of my past. I’m in a state of depression thinking about “what could be” instead of being happy with what is.

They say desire leads to suffering . I think that statement is *technically* true.
I realize I have it within my power … to not desire so much. I can learn to be content with what I currently have. It happened before. To want little. To take joy in the many small pleasure of my life.

My issue is this is that last time I decided to “stop desiring” is exactly the same time period in my life I realize I wasted. If I was bolder , more courageous, more ambitious…. I could have had a lot more and be in a better place.

I feel like even though my desire causes me pain. It’s a necessary pain , because it’s that pain which is forcing me to at least try to get what I want. If I don’t desire, I may look back in 10 years and feel regret. Much like I do now.

Or maybe not. Maybe I’m in a psychic prison of my own creation.

In the grand scheme, is it worth it?

>>28232494
Have you considered living off your savings for a while? Taking advantage of low cost of living countries where digital nomads flock.
>How feasible is it to live in a place like Thailand for around 500 bucks a month or less?
>rent
Go on fazwaz, or dare I say Craigslist, and see what the prices are. The lowest you could conceivably go on rent is like $150 and that's gonna be outside Farang ghettos and in a non-centralized location. It probably doesn't include utilities either
>muh hostel!
You'd be lucky to find $5 dollars a night
>food
A single Thai dish with rice is like $1.5-3 dollars. Anything western is obviously more expensive. So if you wanted to keep your food budget low you'd have to eat Thai food pretty strictly; either from a hole in the wall restaurant or food cart
>misc
So let's say did that. You're left with $170. That's only about 5000 baht. Lowest monthly rate you could get for a motorbike rental is like 3000 baht = $3 dollars a day. Moto taxis are at least a dollar per trip, even on an app like bolt.
You'd also have to factor in the cost of an ED visa (IMO that's the best visa to stay for ~1 year).

So bottom line you could probably survive "comfortably" imo but that's about it. I don't think you'd find it particularly pleasant though. $1000/mo is a lot more ideaI.

It'll be piss-easy. You'll be living with someone who actually cares about you and all of the tension from being around your parents will melt away.

I've been in a similar position. I moved in with my sister at 16 because my parents divorce was turning them into monsters, and I was coming close to killing myself. When I tried to visit my parents home to see my younger siblings, that tension immediately resurfaced. At one point, I stood on their front doorstep with my hand raised to knock on the door and contemplated turning tail and going home - purely because I was already so tense that I couldn't stand it.
I'm 27 now and recently visited my sister's place for a week to babysit while she's out of town. When I came home I realised how much that place felt like 'home' to me, and how much I miss it. I like my current place, but it's just not the same. I loved living with my sister.

Move out and live with your sister.
As long as you contribute to the household, you'll both be happy. Do chores. Study hard. Get a job to help pay the bills. Cook for the household once in a while. All that good stuff.
You won't learn independence or comfort until you're OUT. Trust me, man. It's for the best.

I suggest you get a job to help pay the bills before you bother with moving. It's not fair on your sister to have to support you while you're jobless.

The hard part will be fighting to get YOUR money out of YOUR bank account. Also, contact a lawyer asap for advice on booting them from your account, and getting your money back.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fix yourself first before you fix others. If you improve you automatically will be an example for your daughter. Can you afford therapy? Do that, it can help tremendously. Pursue a skill and keep at it, like programming. If you get good enough, you can get a job.
Take it very slow, it takes years to change imprinted behaviors. Set your goal, then try to do 1/4th of the goal. Try to formulate the immediate next step, e.g. study programming: Research what to do to start (which language) and find a tutorial for that language -> install IDE -> start reading the first page
always the immediate next step, so you don't misguide yourself by "researching" or escaping reality

it can take weeks or months, just try to try again if you fail.

If you are writing here asking for advice, you still do not want to die / give up, you have the necessary minimum life force to start. Again, take it super slow, be grateful for your progress (even if it sounds stupid, being grateful is very good for validating progress).

Friends: The most natural way is to have repeated unplanned encounters. You don't become friends with people on the first meeting (usually, and especially if you are no super social person), try a hobby, go to meetings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28231411
Every person seeks fulfilling uses of their time, but what fulfills us depends on the person. What you need to do is either frame your "downtime" pursuits as worthwhile activities, or replace them with things you find fulfilling that compliment your more active lifestyle.
I bet you wouldn't feel like that time spent passively watching videos was "braindead" if you were watching something educational or challenging. If you turned media into active engagement, perhaps you would feel justified watching it, so maybe force yourself to write out your thoughts on it, or at least digest the media more critically. Of course you don't have to do that, you could try to frame that same activity in your mind as "deserved restful pastime." You're into fitness so I'm sure you're aware that the body does need time to recover, if you don't you're leaving gains on the table, so you could also try framing it in that light. You're just too preoccupied thinking of all the things you've already found value in that the things you haven't yet are perceived as obstructions standing in the way.

tl;dr chillaaaaaaax brah

posts.sub: 24M and haven't felt anything in over two years
posts.com:
Over two years ago, I suddenly (overnight) lost the capacity to experience emotions, or, more properly, any emotional nuance. "Feeling" my emotional state is like running up against a brick wall: I can push and pull all I want, but there's no change: simply an endless emotional baseline. I can be and generally am perfectly amiable and emotive, and I've exhibited signs of disgust, anger, laughter, etc. - it's just that they're all something I perceive myself "feeling", rather than actually feel - there's no real substantiality or nuance.

I've no empathy, for myself or others. No real erotic feeling besides dim chemical impulses towards partial images - never towards whole people. Orgasm feels like very little, and I tend to avoid it, unless I want to induce exhaustion.

I'm at a loss. All the roads have lead nowhere. Shrinks have called this Anhedonia, Alexithymia, or just Aspergers, and prescribed me all sorts of antidepressants, and besides a day-long reversal seemingly triggered by an increase in Bupropion dose (around two years ago, never since replicated), nothing's changed the underlying issue.

I'm not worried I'll do anything drastic. That's part of the problem: I can't even properly panic about what's happened to me. All I have is the dull recognition that, proceeding on this path, my life will get worse and worse, more and more pitiful and wretched - and that I'll continue to regard it with the same, dull, unchanging neutrality. I feel no self-pity here; no pity at all - that's part of the problem: there's a real cathartic release in self-pity, that I so desperately wish I could relive.

I've no real friends anymore, or really any social circle at all. I've always been a wretchedly self-absorbed sperg sort, but I seem to have lost the ability to regard any interaction as anything but a kind of social game - it holds my attention, but lacks any real significance.

Any advice? I really don't know what to do

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Try drugs! Weed turns me into a sentimental crybaby. LSD and mushrooms made me feel way more empathy. Tramadol makes me love everyone.

And while you're on it, remind yourself "This is what emotions are like. It's OK to feel these emotions. I still have these emotions"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28232153
It covers possible origins for this type of delayed maturity like having an overbearing and overprotective mother. It also says that man-children are typically stuck in a state of constant ideation and fantasy which leads them to live a "provisional life" which basically means that you constantly daydream about your ideal future but you don't work towards to it because you still think that your are not ready yet or that the perfect opportunity has not presented to you yet. It explains that this constant fantasy acts more like a mechanism to distract oneself from a failed life. It also covers the fact that man children usually loathe and detest work, specially when it's boring or when they feel unappreciated. Now that i remeber it also touches the fact that manchildren typically believe in some form of "false-individuality" that makes you feel special like a genius or a visionary that cannot be one because the time hasn't come yet, Von Franz argues that this type of mentality comes from being stuck in childhood because children hate boring work and typically feel special for the sole fact of being themselves. Also, keep in mind that because the work is written from a Jungian perspective it also means that like every archetype the manchild or the puer aeternus has positive aspects which are manifested in their tendency to be genuine, empathic, creative and passionate.

That includes coworkers, bosses, clients, etc. Pay doesn’t matter, and I can work pretty much any schedule. It just needs to be something that someone with a basic bachelor’s degree can find entry work in.

Do entry level jobs like this exist? I’m talking things like fire watch jobs- those extinct jobs where you would sit by yourself in a tower for a few months and literally just watching for forest fires. Or like some kind of night shift job in an empty building. Or a content reviewer who looks through reported images/messages to determine if they violate TOS. I would diligently watch paint dry or clean up actual shit if it was something where I knew what to do and didn’t have to talk to other people. How can I find a job like this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28229877
You're coming at it with the wrong mindset. If socialization is your weakness then you want a job that makes you socialize.
I have social anxiety and neeted for 5 years. Got a job 2 years ago that thankfully forced me to talk with other people sometimes. Last week I asked out a woman for the first time in like 6 years. She ghosted me but at least I tried.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28229877
I’m in a similar, though not identical situation. I actually have no problem working with people...if it’s a job where I know what I’m supposed to do and how to do it. The problem is, no entry level jobs actual provide training. They just throw you in and expect you to figure it out. So you either have to constantly be asking coworkers what to do and how (which creates social anxiety because that’s just awkward) or you have to wing it and live in constant fear that someone is going to be mad at you for doing it wrong. And what’s worse is that managers are all either unable or unwilling to give any helpful feedback. They’ll either provide no feedback, or just get on to you for not knowing your job, despite not training you. Maybe find a place where you can volunteer first. With volunteers, there’s no real pressure of expectations, no (real) commitment, and you can learn things and get a feel of what the job is like before applying. Plus, you’ll have the advantage in the interviews since they know you and probably want to return the favor you’ve provided them.

>>28230104
>Like going to travel and staying at hostels, talking to people in another city
I can’t afford to do that; disability only helps with treatment and living expenses. And given what happened to me last time, that would be basically suicidal for me anyway. That approach simply isn’t going to work. Not for me anyway.

Anyway, the entire point of therapy is to teach you cognitive skills as well as use behavioral conditioning, and do so in a way that prevents you from ending up like I did last time. Exposure is a fundamental part of that (Exposure Response Prevention is a common form of cognitive behavioral therapy). But therapists (good ones, anyway), know that simply throwing whatever is causing problems to the patient right at the patient without so much as a thought behind it is the same as tossing a small child in the deep end of the pool to teach him how to swim. Those children that survive will say “lol why don’t hop in and learn”. The children that drown won’t say anything. Seeing as I am the child that can’t swim in this scenario, you might see why I’d rather have a teacher. Eventually, I will reach a point where I can function long term in normal environments. I understand that you can’t expect to fix all your problems with “this one simple trick”, hence why I’m taking the long and grueling route. I don’t expect to get therapy instructions from 4chan, I just want a way to earn a least a little money while I’m working on that.

As for psychedelics, I haven’t done that since college, and there is a reason why. I’m sure it helps some people, but for people like me it just makes everything worse, plus I probably couldn’t afford that long term.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Well, you can actually do easy “by the job” work as a scribe online. Totally free of any real direct interaction with other people. There are a couple of online services that allow anyone to sign up as a scribe. You read through the rules and instructions, and do some practice jobs and then they’ll send you videos/audio files to write captions/transcriptions for. Sounds like pretty much exactly what you’re looking for. But obviously there is a catch: it’s not a real job. More like contracting gig, so no benefits. On top of that, you’ll be earning less than minimum wage unless you’re a savant, because they usually pay by hours of completed content, and the rate is very poor. Bilingual people can make more money, I think. It would give you something to do, though, and some way to make a little bit of money. Might look good to have that work on your resume when you finally do start applying for real jobs, too.

posts.sub: Should I take a risk and go?
posts.com:
I am severely mentally ill and have never done anything right in life.
All my bad choices have led me to being a single mother of a 10 year old and living on disability and have a criminal record and no license or car. I have no social skills which has led to us having a lonely life.

I see my daughter having a terrible future. We have no friends or family and where we live is a secluded city with no escape without some money and a car.

The college here has no valuable courses and there are only low wage jobs here. I dont see myself making any choices that will get us to a better place in life and she could end up living her life as a low earner and even being homeless. Not to mention no support system and not having a good parent to guide her in life. She already has low self esteem and no goals or anything. I let her sit in front of a screen all day.

I have been talking to her father recently. I left to another province with our daughter 6 years ago so its been a long time. We agreed I could possibly leave everything behind here and take a plane to live with him.

He could be the one thing that saves her from a life of misery. But living together wont be easy. We used to fight, and I am still mentally unstable and we might fight again. I will rely on him for rides to work. It could take me years to get my own place and furniture


I will 100% be inconveniencing him. If I dont live with him and just leave my daughter with him she will feel abandoned and also he needs a roomate to pay half the rent so she wouldnt have her own room if I didnt stay to pay the half of rent.

So if I go, it could take me a long time to get my own place and this could make us miserable.

If I stay here, I think its almost a guarantee that my daughter will have a miserable life.

Either choice could end up bad. But I have a better idea of how staying here will end than if I go there and take a risk.

What do I do? I dont want my kid to be miserable

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28232089
Know that nothing has changed between you and the father, if things used to be toxic then they'll be just as bad if not worse. That might be a far worse environment for your daughter than what you got now

The best thing you can do is help her find a course that she enjoys or is passionate about, even with low wage jobs. Arguably the most important thing as well is you getting close with her, find something you both like doing and do it once a week or so together, be it shopping, movie night, whatever. If she does get into a relationship at some point she only has you to rely on, regardless of your own circumstances the least you can do is make sure she gets to have a healthy relationship
